update.description:
This PR is a work-in-progress, but is mostly complete. I'm opening it to facilitate discussion on the concept and to check whether this is an avenue that we want to take.

The key features of this PR are the abilities to publish and subscribe to arbitrary raw message data, while only performing serialization or deserialization when it is absolutely necessary.

This probably sounds like it's merely a performance improvement, but it's actually far more important than that: This allows us to subscribe to *any* type of message, including messages whose protobuf descriptors are not available to us (e.g. custom user-defined messages). This feature is necessary for logging in order for us to record custom messages which were generated outside of `ign-msgs`. Protobuf will always fail to deserialize a message whose type was generated in a library that is not linked to the current application, so this PR allows us to skip the deserialization step and send the message data directly into the logger.

The key implementation detail in this PR is that I've introduced a new type of subscription handler: `RawSubscriptionHandler`. This new subscription handler is managed independently of the existing `ISubscriptionHandler`.

TODO List:

1. Create tests for the raw publisher and subscriber functions

2. Create an unsubscribe function for raw subscriptions

This PR may result in some backlash (for reasons that I'll enumerate below), so I'm completely open to  discussing and reversing the things that I'm proposing in this PR. Here's a list of what I suspect may be controversial:

1. There's a significant refactoring of `Node::Publisher::Publish(~)` and `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()`. My goal in the refactoring was to keep the changes as DRY as possible. In particular, publishing a raw message to local subscribers is extremely similar to receiving a message from remote publishers and passing it along to your node's local subscribers. Therefore, most of the functionality of `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()` has been refactored into `NodeShared::CheckHandlerInfo(~)` and `NodeShared::TriggerSubscriberCallbacks(~)`.

2. Generally we want to discourage end-users from doing anything with raw messages, but we want the API for it to be publicly exposed for our own use, and perhaps for advanced users to take advantage of. Therefore, I've introduced an `Advanced` API design pattern: To publish a raw message, you call `publisher->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawPublish(...)`. To create a raw subscription, you would call `node->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawSubscribe(...)`. Since these features are hidden behind the `UseAdvancedFeatures()` functions, it's painfully obvious that these are advanced features which are only meant for advanced users. If we don't like this design pattern, I can easily move `RawPublish` and `RawSubscribe` into the normal API and get rid of the `Advanced` classes.

3. In the definition of [RawSubscriptionHandler](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/af616bbfe39865c1ce4ab70556f6478389c68240/include/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh?at=RawPublishSubscribe&fileviewer=file-view-default#SubscriptionHandler.hh-329) I'm introducing a pimpl design pattern which is a bit stylistically different than what we've been using so far. Instead of creating a `PrivateXXX` class, we create a `XXX::Implementation` class and name its instance `pimpl`. This pattern is a popular one among pimpl users because it allows us to avoid polluting namespaces with classes that can't be accessed by users. It creates a cleaner code model, which is really nice for users who use autocomplete. I don't know if our `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` pattern is considered finalized in our style guide or if we've just been using it to be consistent, but I wanted to throw this suggestion out there to see what people think. I can easily switch it over to `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` if we would rather remain consistent.
update.title: [WIP] Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data
update.reason: This is being replaced by pull request #251

content.raw:
This compiler error only seems to happen with protobuf3 which isn't available on `apt-get`, so it'll be a bit of a chore for me to recreate it on my machine.

It seems that `google/protobuf/stubs/casts.h` is not available in protobuf2. I guess we can wrap that `#include` directive, similarly to the `#if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION > 2999999` where the issue occurs.

Incidentally, is there a reason we use `#if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION >= 2999999` instead of `#if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION >= 3000000`? I feel like the latter expresses its purpose a bit more clearly.
content.html:
This compiler error only seems to happen with protobuf3 which isn't available on apt-get, so it'll be a bit of a chore for me to recreate it on my machine.

It seems that google/protobuf/stubs/casts.h is not available in protobuf2. I guess we can wrap that #include directive, similarly to the #if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION > 2999999 where the issue occurs.

Incidentally, is there a reason we use #if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION >= 2999999 instead of #if GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION >= 3000000? I feel like the latter expresses its purpose a bit more clearly.

content.raw:
I just realized, one thing that gets lost with this approach is if

1. There are no remote subscribers, and
2. None of the raw local subscribers are subscribed to this message type

then this proposed implementation will serialize the message even though it doesn't need to.

I'm not sure how important you consider that performance benefit to be.
content.html:
I just realized, one thing that gets lost with this approach is if

  1. There are no remote subscribers, and
  2. None of the raw local subscribers are subscribed to this message type

then this proposed implementation will serialize the message even though it doesn't need to.

I'm not sure how important you consider that performance benefit to be.

content.raw: After reading the in-code comment on the commit more closely, it seems the view is that messages that are missing some required fields should not be passed to local subscribers. That makes sense since it will ensure that local and remote subscribers consistently see the same messages.

That makes sense since it will ensure that local and remote subscribers consistently see the same messages.

content.raw:
That looks good. Although we could still pass the `_msg` object along to local non-raw subscribers before quitting if it fails to serialize.

It seems that serialization failure can occur if a "required" field is missing, so it's not impossible. I guess the question is whether we want to support passing along messages with missing required fields, but only to local subscribers.
content.html:
That looks good. Although we could still pass the _msg object along to local non-raw subscribers before quitting if it fails to serialize.

It seems that serialization failure can occur if a "required" field is missing, so it's not impossible. I guess the question is whether we want to support passing along messages with missing required fields, but only to local subscribers.

content.raw:
According to [`TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/dc8d5c17452947ae1481e331c237ab88923d0104/src/TopicUtils.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#TopicUtils.cc-110), the `@<partition>@` is always the first part of the fully qualified topic name, so the assumption should be valid.

Incidentally, I think what we should do is change the parameter name `_topicWithPartition` to `_fullyQualifiedTopicName` and add `\sa TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName` to the documentation of `SetTopicAndPartition(~)`.

Paging @sloretz
content.html:
According to TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName, the @<partition>@ is always the first part of the fully qualified topic name, so the assumption should be valid.

Incidentally, I think what we should do is change the parameter name _topicWithPartition to _fullyQualifiedTopicName and add \sa TopicUtils::FullyQualifiedName to the documentation of SetTopicAndPartition(~).

Paging @sloretz

content.raw:
That's correct, although I'd recommend keeping it like this anyway. One of the recommended practices when using PIMPL is for the user-facing classes to be nothing but very light wrappers for the underlying implementation class. The implementation class is where the heavy lifting should be done, rather than just being a container for data fields. This usually makes refactoring easier, and makes code cleaner (e.g. you don't need to use `dataPtr->` over and over again in your implementations).

I understand that our libraries are still transitioning from being non-PIMPL to using PIMPL, but I'd suggest we take advantage of opportunities to move further towards idiomatic PIMPL whenever we can. If you have a strong preference for mixing PIMPL and non-PIMPL idioms, I can move the function back to where it was.
content.html:
That's correct, although I'd recommend keeping it like this anyway. One of the recommended practices when using PIMPL is for the user-facing classes to be nothing but very light wrappers for the underlying implementation class. The implementation class is where the heavy lifting should be done, rather than just being a container for data fields. This usually makes refactoring easier, and makes code cleaner (e.g. you don't need to use dataPtr-> over and over again in your implementations).

I understand that our libraries are still transitioning from being non-PIMPL to using PIMPL, but I'd suggest we take advantage of opportunities to move further towards idiomatic PIMPL whenever we can. If you have a strong preference for mixing PIMPL and non-PIMPL idioms, I can move the function back to where it was.

content.raw: The consensus is to not use `Advanced`, so I'll go ahead and remove it.
content.html: The consensus is to not use Advanced, so I'll go ahead and remove it.

content.raw:
Subscribers are completely agnostic to the publishers. There are now two subscription options: (1) the normal `Subscribe(~)` that has always existed, and (2) `RawSubscribe(~)` which allows the subscriber to receive the raw serialized data.

Both `Subscribe(~)` and `RawSubscribe(~)` can receive messages from all combinations of [ local | remote ] and [ ordinary | raw ] publishers. I set it up so that serialization or deserialization only happens (at most) once and only occurs when necessary.
content.html:
Subscribers are completely agnostic to the publishers. There are now two subscription options: (1) the normal Subscribe(~) that has always existed, and (2) RawSubscribe(~) which allows the subscriber to receive the raw serialized data.

Both Subscribe(~) and RawSubscribe(~) can receive messages from all combinations of [ local | remote ] and [ ordinary | raw ] publishers. I set it up so that serialization or deserialization only happens (at most) once and only occurs when necessary.

content.raw:
`MessageInfo` is just wrapping up some POD (just a set of strings so far). We only use pimpl for it because it's user-facing, so we want to keep its ABI stable. Copying should be a natural and desirable operation for it. As an example, we might want to build up a buffer of `MessageInfo` objects before creating a batch SQL command to record them to the log.

That being said, I should make sure that a move constructor is available for it. I think it should be created by default, but it's best to be explicit.
content.html:
MessageInfo is just wrapping up some POD (just a set of strings so far). We only use pimpl for it because it's user-facing, so we want to keep its ABI stable. Copying should be a natural and desirable operation for it. As an example, we might want to build up a buffer of MessageInfo objects before creating a batch SQL command to record them to the log.

That being said, I should make sure that a move constructor is available for it. I think it should be created by default, but it's best to be explicit.

content.raw: I'm in favor of using documentation, tutorials, and examples to instruct users how to use an API instead of hiding parts of the API. You can use the `\attention`, `\warning`, or `\note` doxygen commands to let users know that a function or class is for advanced use.
content.html: I'm in favor of using documentation, tutorials, and examples to instruct users how to use an API instead of hiding parts of the API. You can use the \attention, \warning, or \note doxygen commands to let users know that a function or class is for advanced use.

content.raw: Is a copy constructor required? Having a copy constructor can lead to accidental copies.
content.html: Is a copy constructor required? Having a copy constructor can lead to accidental copies.

content.raw:
Yeah, it's a non-trivial amount of legwork just so we can scream at the user "you probably don't want to touch this".

I think it comes down to a value judgment of just how important it is for us to indicate that the raw subscriptions and raw publications are meant for special use cases.

In any case, it was an interesting exercise to put it together, and seeing it in action probably makes it easier to judge.
content.html:

I think it comes down to a value judgment of just how important it is for us to indicate that the raw subscriptions and raw publications are meant for special use cases.

In any case, it was an interesting exercise to put it together, and seeing it in action probably makes it easier to judge.
